newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa retreats after hitting near 3-mth high.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa retreats after hitting near 3-mth high.

text.p: Cocoa futures recovered their nerve in afternoon dealings on Wednesday following a new spate of technical short covering, but prices retreated from their peaks.

Benchmark May cocoa reached a nearly three month high of 945 stg per tonne after crossing smoothly the initial 938 stg barrier, but the close below this initial resistance level was somewhat discouraging for longs.

"It's a bit disappointing that it closed below 938," said one trader. He described sentiment as "mixed" after a surge of 80 stg or almost ten percent since last week, mainly on the back of improving chart picture.
May ended the day at 933 stg, up three stg, while further forwards recorded gains of up to 13 stg. Turnover totalled 11,007 lots, of which May grabbed a hefty 5,825.
The May structure was tightening with May/Dec trading at 33 stg but on the closing call the May/July came out to 14 stg from 11 during the day, traders said.
The market had a hesistant start absorbing early hedges, but the ensuing rally helped tighten the arbitrage against New York as stop losses were triggered at 938, traders said.
Although technically the market should look to extent gains to the December high of 942 some players were sceptical, saying more fundamental clues were needed to justify the rally.
But these were absent, especially with prospects for the Ivorian midcrop now looking better after weather experts forecast showers in cocoa areas at the end of this week.
Another setback remained to be lack of aggressive industry buying.
German cocoa traders said they were not convinced by the technical reversal of the market.
"As far as buyers are concerned there is plenty of cocoa around and the fundamentals are unchanged," said one trader.
